intro: Hyacinthoides non-scripta subsp. hispanica, commonly known as the Spanish bluebell, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from pale blue to deep violet. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are glaucous in appearance. It thrives in woodland and shaded areas, preferring well-drained, acidic soils. The Spanish bluebell is an important part of the local flora and is often associated with ancient woodlands in southern Europe.
